title: Building a Sustainable Single-Use Coffee Cup - Advertising Specialty Institute
summary: The Good Cup is a recyclable, plastic-free coffee cup designed with an origami-style integrated lid to reduce environmental waste. Co-founders Cyril Drouet and Paul Wong developed it to address the environmental issues associated with single-use cups, which often cannot be recycled due to plastic linings. Made from FSC-certified paper, it aims to minimize the environmental impact by eliminating the need for a separate lid and incorporates sustainable materials. The product has gained international use and recognition for its innovative approach to reducing plastic waste.
green_innovation: TRUE: This is green innovation because The Good Cup significantly reduces environmental impact by using recyclable and compostable materials while eliminating the need for a separate plastic lid, thus addressing issues related to single-use plastic waste.
business_innovation: TRUE: This is a business innovation because The Good Cup introduces a new product design that significantly differs from traditional coffee cups, improving the environmental sustainability of single-use coffee containers.
green_product: TRUE: The Good Cup qualifies as a green product because it is designed to minimize environmental impact throughout its life cycle, using sustainable materials and methods that promote recycling and composting.
green_process: FALSE: This is not a green process. Although the product is sustainable, the article does not describe the production or operational methods associated with the creation of The Good Cup.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 326199 - All Other Plastics Product Manufacturing, 322213 - Paperboard Containers and Boxes Manufacturing, 541613 - Marketing Consulting Services, 424490 - Other Grocery and Related Products Merchant Wholesalers.
greenwashing: FALSE: The article does not describe greenwashing. It presents a legitimate innovation focused on reducing environmental waste without misleading claims about its sustainability.

title: Waste Reduction and Recycling | Saskatchewan State of the Environment â€“ 2023 - Government of Saskatchewan
summary: Saskatchewan aims to reduce waste per person by 30% by 2030 and 50% by 2040, focusing on enhancing waste diversion through reducing, reusing, and recycling. Various programs and regulations, including extended producer responsibility (EPR), are in place to promote responsible waste management and recycling of materials like used oil and plastics. The province has seen a decrease in per capita landfill waste, with notable recycling efforts such as the Saskatchewan Paint Stewardship Program and tire recycling initiatives. The Solid Waste Management Strategy ensures economic growth aligns with responsible waste management and environmental protection, promoting a circular economy.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article describes various initiatives promoting waste reduction, recycling, and sustainable resource management, which contribute to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: FALSE - While there are programs mentioned, the article does not specifically highlight a new or improved product or business process introduced to the market by a firm.
green_product: FALSE - The article discusses programs and initiatives rather than specific goods or services that are distinctly categorized as green products.
green_process: TRUE - The article highlights processes such as recycling and waste management programs that aim to minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 812220 - Cosmetology and Barber Schools, 311119 - Other Animal Food Manufacturing, 541620 - Environmental Consulting Services.
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not appear to engage in misleading marketing about environmental benefits; it discusses genuine strategies and actions taken by Saskatchewan towards waste reduction and environmental stewardship.
